qas.question: People over the age of 35 reacted to the bombings with what?
Why had German raids decreased between 1916-1918?
How many people were killed by bomb drops during the first World War?
How many bombs had been dropped?

context: The attitude of the Air Ministry was in contrast to the experiences of the First World War when a few German bombers caused physical and psychological damage out of all proportion to their numbers. Around 280 short tons (250 t) (<a3_0>9,000<a3_0/> bombs) had been dropped, killing <a2_0>1,413<a2_0/> people and injuring 3,500 more. Most people aged 35 or over remembered the threat and greeted the bombings with <a0_0>great trepidation<a0_0/>. From 1916–1918, German raids had diminished against <a1_0>countermeasures<a1_0/> which demonstrated defence against night air raids was possible.
